<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">We report the structure of a one-dimensional chain compound formed by manganese(II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) and nitroxide radical 2-diethylin-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1-imidazol-1-oxy-3-oxide (NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH, which crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=28.4028(2) Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=13.4494(8) Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=23.8493(1) Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=124.4110(1)°, and <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=8. In the compound Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units are bridged by the MITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> radical which is <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-coordinated toward the manganese originating a chain. The magnetic susceptibility in the range of temperature 4–300 K is typical of a ferrimagnetic chain formed by alternating spins 5/2 and spins 1/2.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

We report the structure of a one-dimensional chain compound formed by manganese(II) hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) and nitroxide radical 2-diethylin-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1-imidazol-1-oxy-3-oxide (NITPhNEt2), Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2⋅C2H5OH, which crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group with a=28.4028(2) Å, b=13.4494(8) Å, c=23.8493(1) Å, β=124.4110(1)°, and Z=8. In the compound Mn(hfac)2 units are bridged by the MITPhNEt2 radical which is cis-coordinated toward the manganese originating a chain. The magnetic susceptibility in the range of temperature 4-300 K is typical of a ferrimagnetic chain formed by alternating spins 5/2 and spins 1/2.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In the field of molecular magnetic materials important results have been obtained for compounds including stable organic radicals coordinated to paramagnetic ions . In particular, low-dimensional manganese(II) and nitroxides radical compounds are currently actively investigated, both as interesting research objects on their own and also as intermediate building blocks in order to synthesize bulk molecular-based magnets .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the field of molecular magnetic materials important results have been obtained for compounds including stable organic radicals coordinated to paramagnetic ions . In particular, low-dimensional manganese(II) and nitroxides radical compounds are currently actively investigated, both as interesting research objects on their own and also as intermediate building blocks in order to synthesize bulk molecular-based magnets .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">We have recently synthesized a one-dimensional chain assembling manganese(II) hexafluoroacetylacetonates, Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and nitronyl nitroxide 2-diethylin-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1-imidazol-1-oxy-3-oxide, NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, whose general formula is<display>
<formula>

</formula>
</display>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We have recently synthesized a one-dimensional chain assembling manganese(II) hexafluoroacetylacetonates, Mn(hfac)2, and nitronyl nitroxide 2-diethylin-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-4,5-dihydro-1-imidazol-1-oxy-3-oxide, NITPhNEt2, whose general formula is

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The radical as a 1,3-bridging ligand can bind to two different atoms yielding a chain. In this way, we hoped to obtain substantial exchange interaction between the different spins. Ferromagnetic chains with copper have been reported . We report here the magnetic properties of a ferrimagnetic chain of general formula Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH and its X-ray crystal structure and EPR. This work is profitable to extend our knowledge of one-dimensional magnetic chains.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The radical as a 1,3-bridging ligand can bind to two different atoms yielding a chain. In this way, we hoped to obtain substantial exchange interaction between the different spins. Ferromagnetic chains with copper have been reported . We report here the magnetic properties of a ferrimagnetic chain of general formula Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2⋅CH3CH2OH and its X-ray crystal structure and EPR. This work is profitable to extend our knowledge of one-dimensional magnetic chains.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complex</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was prepared according to the literature method . NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> radical was prepared as previously described . Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH was obtained by suspending 1 mmol Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 20 ml of warm <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-heptane and adding a solution of 5 ml alcohol–dichloromethane containing 1 mmol of NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 60°C. Immediately the solution become green. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min and filtered, the filtrate was cooled. Dark-green single crystals were obtained after some days. Anal. calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">29</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>F<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>MnN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>: C, 42.46; H, 4.15; N, 5.12; found: C, 42.63; H, 3.86; N, 5.22.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis of the complex

Mn(hfac)2⋅2H2O was prepared according to the literature method . NITPhNEt2 radical was prepared as previously described . Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2⋅C2H5OH was obtained by suspending 1 mmol Mn(hfac)2⋅2H2O in 20 ml of warm n-heptane and adding a solution of 5 ml alcohol-dichloromethane containing 1 mmol of NITPhNEt2 at 60°C. Immediately the solution become green. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min and filtered, the filtrate was cooled. Dark-green single crystals were obtained after some days. Anal. calc. for C29H34F12MnN3O7: C, 42.46; H, 4.15; N, 5.12; found: C, 42.63; H, 3.86; N, 5.22.

elements.content: X-ray analysis: structure determinationA dark-green crystal with dimensions 0.35×0.30×0.20 mm was mounted on a glass fiber in a random orientation. Diffraction data were collected at room temperature on a computer-controlled BRUKER SMART 1000 diffractometer equipped with MoKα radiation and a graphite monochromator (λ=0.71073 A ̊ ). More details are given in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray analysis: structure determination

A dark-green crystal with dimensions 0.35×0.30×0.20 mm  was mounted on a glass fiber in a random orientation. Diffraction data were collected at room temperature on a computer-controlled BRUKER SMART 1000 diffractometer equipped with MoKα radiation and a graphite monochromator (λ=0.71073   A  ̊ ). More details are given in  .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The X-ray structure analysis revealed that the compound belongs to the monoclinic system, space group C2/c. The structure was solved using direct method by the S<ce:small-caps>HELXS</ce:small-caps>-97 program  and refined using the full-matrix least-squares method by the S<ce:small-caps>HELX</ce:small-caps>-97 package of the program. The refinement converged to <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>=0.0606 and wR2=0.1624.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The X-ray structure analysis revealed that the compound belongs to the monoclinic system, space group C2/c. The structure was solved using direct method by the SHELXS-97 program  and refined using the full-matrix least-squares method by the SHELX-97 package of the program. The refinement converged to R=0.0606 and wR2=0.1624.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>EPR and magnetic measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The polycrystalline powder EPR spectra were recorded with a JESFEIXG EPR spectrometer operating at X-band frequency. Magnetic susceptibility measurement of a crystalline sample was carried out in the temperature range 4–300 K on a Maglab system2000 magnetometer at a field strength of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>000 G. Data were corrected for the magnetization of the sample holder and for diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal table).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
EPR and magnetic measurements

The polycrystalline powder EPR spectra were recorded with a JESFEIXG EPR spectrometer operating at X-band frequency. Magnetic susceptibility measurement of a crystalline sample was carried out in the temperature range 4-300 K on a Maglab system2000 magnetometer at a field strength of 10000 G. Data were corrected for the magnetization of the sample holder and for diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal table).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structure</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structure of Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH consists of chains of Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units bridged by NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> radicals. The asymmetric unit is comprised of a Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group, which is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>. The unit cell is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>, where the equivalent chains oriented along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis are clearly visible.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure

The structure of Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2⋅C2H5OH consists of chains of Mn(hfac)2 units bridged by NITPhNEt2 radicals. The asymmetric unit is comprised of a Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2 group, which is shown in  . The unit cell is shown in  , where the equivalent chains oriented along the a-axis are clearly visible.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Each manganese(II) ion is hexacoordinated by four oxygen atoms of two different hfac molecules and by two oxygen atoms of different NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> radicals. The other oxygen atoms of the two radicals are coordinated to the two adjacent manganese(II) ions. The two radicals are <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-coordinated around manganese, which is similar to Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITR . The Mn–O distances are almost constant in the complex, ranging from 2.112(3) to 2.184(3) Å. The coordination octahedron is severely distorted, probably in order to decrease steric hindrance between the hfacs and the radicals. The O(3)–Mn(1)–O(6) angle is about 79.99(10)°, which reveals that the two radicals are <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-coordinated. Selected bond distances and bond angles are given 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each manganese(II) ion is hexacoordinated by four oxygen atoms of two different hfac molecules and by two oxygen atoms of different NITPhNEt2 radicals. The other oxygen atoms of the two radicals are coordinated to the two adjacent manganese(II) ions. The two radicals are cis-coordinated around manganese, which is similar to Mn(hfac)2⋅NITR . The Mn-O distances are almost constant in the complex, ranging from 2.112(3) to 2.184(3) Å. The coordination octahedron is severely distorted, probably in order to decrease steric hindrance between the hfacs and the radicals. The O(3)-Mn(1)-O(6) angle is about 79.99(10)°, which reveals that the two radicals are cis-coordinated. Selected bond distances and bond angles are given  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Magnetic properties and EPR</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Magnetic susceptibility data were collected on a crystalline sample. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH was investigated in the range 4–300 K and at a magnetic field of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>000 G. The variation curves of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> vs. <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> are represented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> value of 5.51 B.M. at 300 K is smaller than the value of 6.16 B.M. expected for isolated <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=1/2 spin of one radical and <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=5/2 spins of d<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> Mn(II), indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(II) ion and radical. <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> increases slowly on lowering temperature indicating that the Mn-radical moieties are in the ferrimagnetic chain. Since the manganese and radical spins are different in magnitude, even their antiparalleled alignment yields a large effective magnetic moment and consequently a large value of <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties and EPR

Magnetic susceptibility data were collected on a crystalline sample. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2⋅C2H5OH was investigated in the range 4-300 K and at a magnetic field of 10000 G. The variation curves of χ M and μ eff vs. T are represented in  . The μ eff value of 5.51 B.M. at 300 K is smaller than the value of 6.16 B.M. expected for isolated S=1/2 spin of one radical and S=5/2 spins of d5 Mn(II), indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(II) ion and radical. μ eff increases slowly on lowering temperature indicating that the Mn-radical moieties are in the ferrimagnetic chain. Since the manganese and radical spins are different in magnitude, even their antiparalleled alignment yields a large effective magnetic moment and consequently a large value of μ eff.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In order to understand quantitatively the magnitude of magnetic interaction, the following empirical expression  for ordered Mn(II) and radical and molecular-field correction have been used to fit the experimental data:<display>
<formula>
<ce:label>(1)</ce:label>
<math altimg="si7.gif">χ<inf loc="post">
<rm>chain</rm>
</inf>=(g<sup loc="post">2</sup>/4T)(4.75−1.62370α+2.05042α<sup loc="post">2</sup>−4.52588α<sup loc="post">3</sup>−8.64256α<sup loc="post">4</sup>)/(1+0.77968α−1.56527α<sup loc="post">2</sup>−1.57333α<sup loc="post">3</sup>−0.11666α<sup loc="post">4.5</sup>),</math>
</formula>
</display>
<display>
<formula>
<ce:label>(2)</ce:label>
<math altimg="si8.gif">α=|<rm>J</rm>|/<rm>kT</rm>,</math>
</formula>
</display>
<display>
<formula>
<ce:label>(3)</ce:label>
<math altimg="si9.gif">χ<inf loc="post">
<rm>M</rm>
</inf>=χ<inf loc="post">
<rm>chain</rm>
</inf>/1−(zJ/Ng<sup loc="post">2</sup>β<sup loc="post">2</sup>)χ<inf loc="post">
<rm>chain</rm>
</inf>.</math>
</formula>
</display>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to understand quantitatively the magnitude of magnetic interaction, the following empirical expression  for ordered Mn(II) and radical and molecular-field correction have been used to fit the experimental data:  (1) χ chain =(g2/4T)(4.75-1.62370α+2.05042α2-4.52588α3-8.64256α4)/(1+0.77968α-1.56527α2-1.57333α3-0.11666α4.5),     (2) α=|J|/kT,     (3) χ M =χ chain /1-(zJ/Ng2β2)χ chain .

<ce:inf loc="post">Mn</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">Rad</ce:inf> factors were assumed to be equal. <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>zJ</ce:italic> represent the intrachain and interchain interaction parameter, respectively. The best fit shown as the solid line in  afforded the parameter values <math altimg="si10.gif">J=−34.2<ce:hsp sp="0.35"></ce:hsp>
<rm>cm</rm>
<sup loc="post">−1</sup>
</math>, <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>=2.03, <math altimg="si11.gif">zJ=−1.9<ce:hsp sp="0.35"></ce:hsp>
<rm>cm</rm>
<sup loc="post">−1</sup>
</math>, agreement factor <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>=∑[(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">obs</ce:inf>−(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">calc</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>/∑[(<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">obs</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>=4.9×10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>. From 300 to 100 K, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> is nearly constant, because of the weak antiferromagnetic interaction of the intrachains. With the lowering of temperature, long-distance order interaction in the chain increases, which results in the increase in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>. Below 30 K, the antiferromagnetic couplings between chains become obvious which leads the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> to decrease sharply.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this approach, the g Mn and g Rad factors were assumed to be equal. J and zJ represent the intrachain and interchain interaction parameter, respectively. The best fit shown as the solid line in  afforded the parameter values J=-34.2 cm -1 , g=2.03, zJ=-1.9 cm -1 , agreement factor F=∑[(χ M)obs-(χ M)calc]2/∑[(χ M)obs]2=4.9×10-4. From 300 to 100 K, μ eff is nearly constant, because of the weak antiferromagnetic interaction of the intrachains. With the lowering of temperature, long-distance order interaction in the chain increases, which results in the increase in μ eff. Below 30 K, the antiferromagnetic couplings between chains become obvious which leads the μ eff to decrease sharply.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>EPR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Polycrystalline powder EPR spectrum of the complex Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 110 K shows an isotropic feature at <ce:italic>g</ce:italic>=2.03, which is consistent with the result of magnetic experiments. Line width <ce:italic>ΔH</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">pp</ce:inf> is about 594 G. Comparing with the previous paper , these results agree well with the liner-chain structure and with the observed magnetic properties. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL3"></ce:float-anchor> gives the contrasting results of this work and the literature . The line width of EPR spectrum is in the reverse order of the calculated <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> value. Since <ce:italic>ΔH</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">pp</ce:inf> is expected to be inversely proportional to <ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1/3</ce:sup> in one-dimensional materials , the two set of data, EPR and magnetic fit, appear to be consistent. The absolute <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> values for Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are much smaller than the one for Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPh. This may be due to the electronic effect of the substituting group. From the inductivity point of view, NITPh is a stronger donor ligand than NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> because the electronegativity of the –PhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group is larger than that of the –Ph group. The effective antiferromagnetic coupling may be given when the radical ligand is a stronger donor .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
EPR spectra

Polycrystalline powder EPR spectrum of the complex Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2 at 110 K shows an isotropic feature at g=2.03, which is consistent with the result of magnetic experiments. Line width ΔH pp is about 594 G. Comparing with the previous paper , these results agree well with the liner-chain structure and with the observed magnetic properties.   gives the contrasting results of this work and the literature . The line width of EPR spectrum is in the reverse order of the calculated J value. Since ΔH pp is expected to be inversely proportional to J 1/3 in one-dimensional materials , the two set of data, EPR and magnetic fit, appear to be consistent. The absolute J values for Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2 are much smaller than the one for Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPh. This may be due to the electronic effect of the substituting group. From the inductivity point of view, NITPh is a stronger donor ligand than NITPhNEt2 because the electronegativity of the -PhNEt2 group is larger than that of the -Ph group. The effective antiferromagnetic coupling may be given when the radical ligand is a stronger donor .

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complex</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was prepared according to the literature method . NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> radical was prepared as previously described . Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH was obtained by suspending 1 mmol Mn(hfac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 20 ml of warm <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-heptane and adding a solution of 5 ml alcohol–dichloromethane containing 1 mmol of NITPhNEt<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 60°C. Immediately the solution become green. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min and filtered, the filtrate was cooled. Dark-green single crystals were obtained after some days. Anal. calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">29</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>F<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>MnN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>: C, 42.46; H, 4.15; N, 5.12; found: C, 42.63; H, 3.86; N, 5.22.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis of the complex

Mn(hfac)2⋅2H2O was prepared according to the literature method . NITPhNEt2 radical was prepared as previously described . Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2⋅C2H5OH was obtained by suspending 1 mmol Mn(hfac)2⋅2H2O in 20 ml of warm n-heptane and adding a solution of 5 ml alcohol-dichloromethane containing 1 mmol of NITPhNEt2 at 60°C. Immediately the solution become green. After the mixture was stirred for 10 min and filtered, the filtrate was cooled. Dark-green single crystals were obtained after some days. Anal. calc. for C29H34F12MnN3O7: C, 42.46; H, 4.15; N, 5.12; found: C, 42.63; H, 3.86; N, 5.22.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties and EPR

Magnetic susceptibility data were collected on a crystalline sample. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2⋅C2H5OH was investigated in the range 4-300 K and at a magnetic field of 10000 G. The variation curves of χ M and μ eff vs. T are represented in  . The μ eff value of 5.51 B.M. at 300 K is smaller than the value of 6.16 B.M. expected for isolated S=1/2 spin of one radical and S=5/2 spins of d5 Mn(II), indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling between the Mn(II) ion and radical. μ eff increases slowly on lowering temperature indicating that the Mn-radical moieties are in the ferrimagnetic chain. Since the manganese and radical spins are different in magnitude, even their antiparalleled alignment yields a large effective magnetic moment and consequently a large value of μ eff.

In this approach, the g Mn and g Rad factors were assumed to be equal. J and zJ represent the intrachain and interchain interaction parameter, respectively. The best fit shown as the solid line in  afforded the parameter values J=-34.2 cm -1 , g=2.03, zJ=-1.9 cm -1 , agreement factor F=∑[(χ M)obs-(χ M)calc]2/∑[(χ M)obs]2=4.9×10-4. From 300 to 100 K, μ eff is nearly constant, because of the weak antiferromagnetic interaction of the intrachains. With the lowering of temperature, long-distance order interaction in the chain increases, which results in the increase in μ eff. Below 30 K, the antiferromagnetic couplings between chains become obvious which leads the μ eff to decrease sharply.

EPR spectra

Polycrystalline powder EPR spectrum of the complex Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2 at 110 K shows an isotropic feature at g=2.03, which is consistent with the result of magnetic experiments. Line width ΔH pp is about 594 G. Comparing with the previous paper , these results agree well with the liner-chain structure and with the observed magnetic properties.   gives the contrasting results of this work and the literature . The line width of EPR spectrum is in the reverse order of the calculated J value. Since ΔH pp is expected to be inversely proportional to J 1/3 in one-dimensional materials , the two set of data, EPR and magnetic fit, appear to be consistent. The absolute J values for Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPhNEt2 are much smaller than the one for Mn(hfac)2⋅NITPh. This may be due to the electronic effect of the substituting group. From the inductivity point of view, NITPh is a stronger donor ligand than NITPhNEt2 because the electronegativity of the -PhNEt2 group is larger than that of the -Ph group. The effective antiferromagnetic coupling may be given when the radical ligand is a stronger donor .
